content: This revision is required in the 2005 Package X, page 14. The internet version of the Publication 1001, page 4, will be available for download on 03/29/06.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td b i span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: FTB conformed by date change to AJCA Act Section 840 as explained on page 4 of our Legislative Change Notice for AB 115 (Stats. 2005, Ch. 691) regarding IRC Section 121(d)(10); property acquired in a like-kind exchange.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Publication 1001, page 8, on the Gain on sale of personal residence bullet:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: For sale or exchanges after 5/6/97, federal law allows an exclusion of gain on the sale of a personal residence in the amount of $250,000 ($500,000 if married filing jointly). The taxpayer must have owned and occupied the residence as a principal residence for at least 2 of the 5 years before the sale. California conforms to this provision. However, California taxpayers who served in the Peace Corps during the 5 year period ending on the date of the sale may reduce the 2 year period by the period of service, not to exceed 18 months.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: If there is a difference between the amounts excluded (or depreciated, if recapture applies) for federal and California, complete California Schedule D (540 or 540NR). Transfer the amount from California Schedule D, line 12a, to Schedule CA (540 or 540NR), line 13, column B (if gain is less than federal). Transfer the amount from California Schedule D, line 12b, to Schedule CA (540 or 540NR), line 13, column C (if gain is more than federal).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: This change must be made in 2005 Package X, page 18; and the Publication 1001 page 8. A revised internet version is available for download as of 3/9/06.

content: Publication 1001, Supplemental Guidelines to California Adjustments

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Publication 1001, Page 12, bulleted item regarding certain business expenses of reservists, performing artists, and fee-basis governmental officials.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li b span
content: Column 2 (DIFFERENCES BETWEEN FEDERAL AND CALIFORNIA LAW) reads:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Federal law allows a deduction. California conforms to deductions regarding certain expenses of reservists and fee-basis governmental officials. California has not conformed to deductions of performing artists

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: California has conforms to federal law in the tax treatment of expenses for reservists, performing artists, and fee-basis Governmental officials.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: However, there could be continuing differences in the depreciation deduction such as IRC Section 179 or bonus depreciation.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li b span
content: Column 3 (WHAT TO DO FOR CALIFORNIA) reads:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li p span
content: Enter the amount of expenses claimed for performing artists on Schedule CA (540 or 540NR), line 24, column B.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li p b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: If the federal depreciation deduction is more than the California depreciation deduction, enter the difference on line 24, column B. If the federal depreciation deduction is less than the California depreciation, enter the difference in column C.

content: The Internet version of the form has been revised. A revised copy is available to download on the Internet. This revision is due to the California Legislature enactment of SB 615 (Stats. 2004 CH 388), which makes California law compatible with the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act (Public Law 108-189). ). Income exclusion may decrease total tax liability.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li p span
content: The revision is required on the 2003 Publication 1001, page 1and 2; Package X page 11.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: The California legislature enacted SB 615 (Stats. 2004 CH. 688), which makes California law compatible with Servicemembers Civil Relief Act (Public Law 108-189). This means that servicemembers domiciled outside of California, and their spouses, may exclude the member’s military compensation from gross income when computing the tax rate on nonmilitary income.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Requirements for military servicemembers domiciled in California remain unchanged. Military servicemembers domiciled in California must include their military pay in total income. In addition, they must include their military pay in California source income when stationed in California. However, military pay is not California source income when a servicemember is permanently stationed outside of California.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p b span
content: Differences Between Federal and California Law, page 1:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Special rules apply to active duty military pay. Native Americans with military pay also see "Earning of American Indians" on this page.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p b span
content: It should read, under Earnings of American Indians, page 2:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Federal law taxes income received by Indians from reservation sources.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: California does not tax income earned by tribal members who live in Indian country affiliated with their tribe and receive earning from the same tribal source of which they are members. Military compensation is considered income from tribal sources. For more information get FTB 674, Frequently Asked Questions about the Income Taxation of American Indians.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Native Americans who receive military compensation must re-figure any AGI percentage calculation(s) by first subtracting military compensation from Federal AGI.
